t: Isaiah 14
Mercy on Jacob
For*p the Lord*s will have mercy on Jacob, and will still choose Israel, and settle them in their own land. The strangers will be joined with them, and they will cling to the house of Jacob.

Then people will take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will possess them for servants and maids in the land of the Lord;*s they will take them captive whose captives they were, and rule over their oppressors.
Fall of the King of Babylon
It*p shall come to pass in the day the Lord*s gives you rest from your sorrow, and from your fear and the hard bondage in which you were made to serve,
that you will take up this proverb against the king of Babylon, and say: “How*pn the oppressor has ceased, The*ld golden city ceased!
The*ld Lord*s has broken the staff of the wicked, The*ld scepter of the rulers;
He*ld who struck the people in wrath with a continual stroke, He*ld who ruled the nations in anger, Is*ld persecuted and*i no one hinders.
The*ld whole earth is at rest and*i quiet; They*ld break forth into singing.
Indeed*ld the cypress trees rejoice over you, And*ild the cedars of Lebanon, Saying,*ild ‘Since you were cut down, No*ld woodsman has come up against us.’

“Hell*ln from beneath is excited about you, To*ld meet you*i at your coming; It*ld stirs up the dead for you, All*ld the chief ones of the earth; It*ld has raised up from their thrones All*ld the kings of the nations.
They*ld all shall speak and say to you: ‘Have*ld you also become as weak as we? Have*ld you become like us?
Your*ld pomp is brought down to Sheol, And*ild the sound of your stringed instruments; The*ld maggot is spread under you, And*ld worms cover you.’
The Fall of Lucifer
“How*pn you are fallen from heaven, O*ld Lucifer, son of the morning! How*ild you are cut down to the ground, You*ld who weakened the nations!

For*ld you have said in your heart: ‘I*ld will ascend into heaven, I*ld will exalt my throne above the stars of God; I*ld will also sit on the mount of the congregation On*ld the farthest sides of the north;
I*ld will ascend above the heights of the clouds, I*ld will be like the Most High.’
Yet*ld you shall be brought down to Sheol, To*ld the lowest depths of the Pit.
“Those*ln who see you will gaze at you, And*ild consider you, saying:*i ‘Is*ild this the man who made the earth tremble, Who*ld shook kingdoms,
Who*ld made the world as a wilderness And*ld destroyed its cities, Who*ild did not open the house of his prisoners?’
“All*ln the kings of the nations, All*ld of them, sleep in glory, Everyone*ld in his own house;

But*ld you are cast out of your grave Like*ld an abominable branch, Like*ild the garment of those who are slain, Thrust*ld through with a sword, Who*ld go down to the stones of the pit, Like*ld a corpse trodden underfoot.
You*ld will not be joined with them in burial, Because*ld you have destroyed your land And*ild slain your people. The*ld brood of evildoers shall never be named.
Prepare*ld slaughter for his children Because*ld of the iniquity of their fathers, Lest*ld they rise up and possess the land, And*ld fill the face of the world with cities.”
Babylon Destroyed
“For*pn I will rise up against them,” says the Lord*s of hosts, “And*ld cut off from Babylon the name and remnant, And*ld offspring and posterity,” says the Lord.*s
“I*ld will also make it a possession for the porcupine, And*ld marshes of muddy water; I*ld will sweep it with the broom of destruction,” says the Lord*s of hosts.
Assyria Destroyed
The*pn Lord*s of hosts has sworn, saying, “Surely,*ld as I have thought, so it shall come to pass, And*ld as I have purposed, so*i it shall stand:
That*ld I will break the Assyrian in My land, And*ld on My mountains tread him underfoot. Then*ld his yoke shall be removed from them, And*ld his burden removed from their shoulders.
This*ld is*i the purpose that is purposed against the whole earth, And*ld this is*i the hand that is stretched out over all the nations.
For*ld the Lord*s of hosts has purposed, And*ld who will annul it?*i His*ld hand is*i stretched out, And*ld who will turn it back?”
Philistia Destroyed
This*p is the burden which came in the year that King Ahaz died.

“Do*pn not rejoice, all you of Philistia, Because*ld the rod that struck you is broken; For*ld out of the serpent’s roots will come forth a viper, And*ld its offspring will*i be*i a fiery flying serpent.
The*ld firstborn of the poor will feed, And*ld the needy will lie down in safety; I*ld will kill your roots with famine, And*ld it will slay your remnant.
Wail,*ld O gate! Cry, O city! All*ld you of Philistia are*i dissolved; For*ld smoke will come from the north, And*ld no one will*i be*i alone in his appointed times.”
What*ln will they answer the messengers of the nation? That*ld the Lord*s has founded Zion, And*ld the poor of His people shall take refuge in it.
